Because one gives freely according to one's wishes, one's precepts are pure because one's mind is as one wishes, one is fully patient because one extends one's mind of enlightenment to enemies and friends alike, one is fully vigorous because one's mind is difficult to destroy, one is fully in meditation because one's mind is tranquil, one is fully wise because one's mind is indestructible, one's great compassion grows because one's mind of enlightenment is indestructible, one's great joy grows because one's mind is harmonious and pleasant, one's great equanimity grows because one's mind is unmoving, one's mind is weighty because it is accepted by the buddhas, and one's mind is uninterrupted because the three jewels are unbroken.

To summarize, all TathÄgatas are all inexhaustible. Because of this, the aroused mind is therefore inexhaustible. Because the Three Jewels are uninterrupted, they are inexhaustible. Because one knows that the inherent nature of all dharmas is inexhaustible, it is inexhaustible.
ÅšÄriputra!

As for the pure mind, it is because it does not engage in flattery. As for not engaging in flattery, it is because there is no deceit. As for no deceit, it is because of good discernment. As for good discernment, it is because there is no wrong livelihood. As for no wrong livelihood,
Because the mind is pure and clear, those with pure and clear minds are always upright, and those who are always upright have a special nature.

Because the mind is pure and clear, those with pure and clear minds are always upright, those who are always upright have an exceptional nature, those with an exceptional nature are without contempt or slander, those without contempt or slander have eliminated all crookedness,

those who have eliminated all crookedness have a straightforward mind, those with a straightforward mind enter into what is level and correct, those who enter into what is level and correct have a firm and substantial mind, those with a firm and substantial mind are indestructible,

those who are without companions or equals put an end to slander and contempt, those who put an end to slander and contempt create good karma,

those who create good karma are without blame, those who are without blame eliminate faults, those who eliminate faults are not tormented, those who are not tormented have a true nature, those who have a true nature

do good, being able to do good is because of being without fault, being without fault is because of being without error,

regressing is because of contemplating sentient beings, contemplating sentient beings is because of the deep roots of great compassion,

because of being a refuge, being a refuge is because of being without defilement,
Because of good observation, there is no defilement. Because of no criticism, there is good observation.
Because of no criticism, the mind is purely good. Because of the pure mind, there is no wavering.
Because of no wavering, there is good purity. Because of good purity, there is constant diligence. Because of constant diligence, there is inner purity.
Because of inner purity, there is constant freshness. Because of constant freshness, there is no defilement.
Yes, Shariputra!
The pure-minded one can cut off stinginess and also transform others to cut off stinginess.

The pure-minded one can cut off breaking precepts and also transform others to cut off breaking precepts.ğŸ”½The pure-minded one can cut off anger and also transform others to cut off anger.ğŸ”½The pure-minded one can cut off laziness and also transform others to cut off laziness.
The pure-minded one can cut off a distracted mind and also transform others to cut off a distracted mind.
The pure-minded can eliminate ignorance and also transform others to eliminate ignorance.
ÅšÄriputra!
The pure mind is like this, able to eliminate all unwholesome dharmas and establish all beings in wholesome dharmas. Therefore, it is said that the bodhisattva's pure mind is inexhaustible.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's practice of pure mind is also inexhaustible.

When the bodhisattva practices giving, all see him relinquish all possessions.

The bodhisattvas' practice of loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity is also inexhaustible, as they all see the benefit of rescuing from suffering, the rejoicing and leaping for joy, and the good severing of attachment and aversion. The bodhisattvas' practice of the three pure karmic actions is to be free from the three evil physical actions and the four evil verbal actions, and to be free from the three evil mental actions, namely greed, anger, and wrong views.

The bodhisattvas' practice of being unstingy is because they gather all wisdom;
The bodhisattvas' cultivation of all wisdom is because they encourage other bodhisattvas to give rise to the aspiration for enlightenment;
Encouraging other bodhisattvas to give rise to the aspiration for enlightenment is because they cultivate and abide in wholesome roots;
Cultivating and abiding in wholesome roots is because they vow to head towards the unsurpassed path of enlightenment;
Vowing to the unsurpassed path of enlightenment is because they embrace all the teachings of the buddhas;

Accumulating immeasurable precious treasures is because they request the buddhas to teach;
Requesting the buddhas to teach is because they embrace all teachings;
Embracing all teachings is because they practice the teachings of the great beings;
Those who practice the Dharma of great beings are able to bear heavy responsibilities for sentient beings;

Those who do not abandon the firm adornments accomplish all the good deeds of sentient beings.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!

The bodhisattva also has four kinds of practices that are inexhaustible.

Taking delight in solitude and subduing one's demeanor without being complacent, always delighting in accumulating immeasurable merit without being complacent, seeking much learning and widely understanding various meanings without being complacent, and always aspiring for the wisdom of unsurpassed enlightenment without being complacent. Bodhisattvas also have four inexhaustible practices.

Bodhisattvas also have four inexhaustible practices.

Bodhisattvas also have four inexhaustible practices.

Bodhisattvas also have four inexhaustible practices.
What are the four?
Expounding impermanence, suffering, no-self, and the quiescent nirvana, are called the four inexhaustible practices of bodhisattvas.

To summarize, all the practices of bodhisattvas are inexhaustible. Aspiring for omniscience, venerating omniscience, and looking up to omniscience, omniscience is inexhaustible. Ultimately free from pride, conceit, superiority, self-importance, inferiority, arrogance, and wrong pride, because of good discernment;
Ultimately able to let go, giving to sentient beings without seeking reward;
Ultimately fearless, contemplating the profound Buddha Dharma;
Ultimately progressing, not stagnating;

Moreover, the ultimate means taming and nurturing sentient beings, and with kindness and benefit covering all virtuous people.

With a compassionate mind, they rescue and liberate those who engage in evil actions. They respect and honor the elders, protect those who have no protector, provide refuge to those who have no refuge, illuminate those who are in darkness, support those who have no support, accompany those who have no companion, straighten those who are crooked, guide those who are not good, expose those who are deceitful, purify those with wrong livelihoods, show kindness to those who are kind, to those who are not kind, and to those who are ungrateful, benefit those who are not benefited, and refute false accusations. They are not arrogant to the arrogant, do not slander those who do not slander, and gently reprimand those who need to be reprimanded.
Those who commit evil and protect deviant practices see the practice of skillful means as not being a fault.
They equally respect all those who receive [the teachings], always guide other bodhisattvas, and expound the teachings with gentle words.
They enjoy practicing good dharmas in empty places, are free from seeking material gain, and do not begrudge their bodies and lives.
They have no wrong thoughts because their minds are in a state of cessation;
Their words are free from deceit and flattery because they restrain their verbal faults;
Because their minds are of few desires and always content, they do not seek benefits through wrong actions.
Because their minds are well-regulated, gentle, and free from defilements,
They revolve in saá¹ƒsÄra, being endowed with wholesome roots.
They are able to endure all sufferings for the sake of sentient beings.
This is the great being's all-pervading inexhaustibility.
This bodhisattva's mind can never be destroyed by the afflictions of birth and death.
Why is it so?
Because this mind increases all merits, embraces all sentient beings, and accomplishes inexhaustible wondrous wisdom.
Virtuous One!
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's all-pervading inexhaustibility.

Why is it so?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice giving immeasurably, namely, giving food to those who need food, because it is endowed with life, eloquence, form, strength, and happiness;
giving drink to those who need drink, because it removes thirst and craving;
giving clothes to those who need clothes, because it is endowed with pure form and removes shamelessness and lack of conscience;
giving vehicles to those who need vehicles, because it enables one to attain all kinds of happiness and spiritual powers;
giving lamps to those who need lamps, because it is endowed with the pure Buddha-eye;
giving music to those who need music, because it is endowed with the penetrating divine ear;
giving fragrances to those who need fragrances, because it enables one's body to emit the subtle fragrance;
giving garlands to those who need garlands, because it enables one to attain the seven factors of enlightenment and dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s;
giving various kinds of incense and unguents to those who need them, because it enables one to apply the perfumed body of morality, concentration, and wisdom;

If they need bedding, they give it to them, because they ultimately cut off afflictions and accomplish the wonderful bed and seat of the Brahma Heaven and sages and buddhas;
If they need seats, they give them seats, because they fully accomplish the site of enlightenment in the trichiliocosm and the vajra seat;
They are able to give whatever is needed, because they accomplish all that is needed for enlightenment;
Giving medicine according to illness leads to being free from old age and death, because they fully accomplish the nectar medicine of the Dharma;
If they need servants, they provide them, because they attain mastery and wisdom;
If they give various treasures such as gold, silver, lapis lazuli, crystal, pearls, shells, agate, and coral, it is because they fully possess the thirty-two marks of a great person;
If they give various necklaces, it is because they fully possess the eighty minor marks;
If they give elephants, horses, and carriages, it is because they fully possess the Great Vehicle;
If one gives a garden or forest, one will be endowed with the branches of meditation;
If one gives one's wife and children, one will be endowed with the love of the unsurpassed Dharma;

If one gives one's hands, one will be endowed with the Dharma hands and comfort sentient beings, causing them to attain bliss;
If one gives one's ears and nose, one will be endowed with all faculties and be extremely sharp;
If one gives one's eyes, it is in order to be endowed with the unobstructed Dharma eye;
If one gives one's head, it is in order to be endowed with the most supreme wisdom in the three realms.
If one gives flesh and blood, it is because one wishes to possess what is not solid and firm.

Bodhisattvas do not seek wealth through wrong livelihood and then practice giving. They do not oppress sentient beings, forcefully obtain others' possessions, and then give them to others. They do not give out of fear, shame, stinginess, or miserliness.

Giving without expecting a reward from the recipient, giving without seeking fame, giving without disparaging or praising, giving without arrogance or haughtiness, giving without vexation, giving without regret, giving without self-praise, giving without defilement, giving without expecting karmic retribution, giving without fixed location, giving without anger, defilement, attachment, and so forth.
Giving without tormenting those who come to beg, giving without contempt, giving without turning one's face away,
Giving without tossing things, giving without being careless, giving without not using one's hands, giving without not being constant,
Giving without interruption, giving without jealousy or arrogance, giving without limits, giving according to one's promises,
Giving without trading, giving without discriminating between those who are capable and those who are not, giving without considering those who are not worthy of offerings,

When bodhisattvas practice giving, they are not ridiculed by the wise.
Why is this?
Because they observe emptiness and tranquility when practicing giving, it is inexhaustible.
Because they practice giving without creating anything, it is inexhaustible.
Because they transcend the characteristics of the three realms when practicing giving, it is inexhaustible.
Because they do not grasp when practicing giving, it is inexhaustible.
Because they practice giving for the sake of the fruit of liberation, it is inexhaustible.ğŸ”½Because they practice giving in order to subdue the mÄras, it is inexhaustible.
Because they practice giving in order to sever the bonds of love and desire, it is inexhaustible.ğŸ”½Because they practice giving in order to increase, it is inexhaustible.
Because they practice giving with skillful discrimination, it is inexhaustible.
Assisting in the giving of enlightenment, therefore it is inexhaustible.
Correctly dedicating the gift, therefore it is inexhaustible.

The gift of adorning the site of enlightenment and the fruit of liberation, therefore it is inexhaustible.ğŸ”½This giving is boundless, therefore it is inexhaustible.ğŸ”½This giving is indestructible, therefore it is inexhaustible.
This giving is unceasing, therefore it is inexhaustible.ğŸ”½This giving is vast, therefore it is inexhaustible.ğŸ”½This giving is non-abiding, therefore it is inexhaustible.
This giving is unyielding, therefore it is inexhaustible.
Giving that is unequaled, therefore it is inexhaustible.
This giving progresses towards omniscience, therefore it is inexhaustible.
Yes, Shariputra!
This is called the bodhisattva's practice of giving that is inexhaustible.

Yes, good man!

Yes, ÅšÄriputra!

Upholding the precepts without defect, because one does not rely on other vehicles;ğŸ”½Upholding the precepts without holes, because one is free from evil circumstances;ğŸ”½Upholding the precepts without confusion, because one is not mixed with various afflictions;

Upholding the precept of dignified conduct, because one attains mastery over all wholesome roots;
Upholding the precept of speaking as one does, because humans and gods rejoice;ğŸ”½Upholding the precept of the compassionate mind, because one protects sentient beings;
Upholding the precept of the compassionate mind, because one is able to endure all suffering;ğŸ”½Upholding the precept of the joyful mind, because one's mind is not lazy;
Upholding the precept of the impartial mind, because one is free from attachment and aversion;
Upholding the precept of self-reflection, because one's mind is well-discriminating;

They observe the precepts of not cherishing life, diligently cultivating wholesome roots;ğŸ”½They observe the precepts of non-regret, their minds pure;
They observe the precepts of not engaging in wrong livelihood, their mental activities pure;
They observe the precepts of non-burning, ultimately pure;ğŸ”½They observe the precepts of non-scorching, cultivating wholesome actions;

They observe the precepts of non-distraction, distancing themselves from desires;
Upholding the precepts without arrogance, because the mind is upright;
Upholding the precepts of gentleness, because the mind is without obstruction;
Upholding the precepts of self-control, because there is no harm;
Upholding the precepts of tranquility, because the mind is without defilement;
Upholding the precepts of following speech, because one practices as taught;
Upholding the precepts of transforming sentient beings, because one does not depart from the Dharma of embracing;
Upholding the precepts of protecting the true Dharma, because one does not contradict reality.
Upholding the precepts of accomplishing according to one's wishes, because one's mind is impartial towards all sentient beings;
Upholding the precepts of being close to the Buddha, because one aspires to the unsurpassed precepts of the TathÄgata;
Upholding the precepts of entering the Buddha's samÄdhi, because one is fully endowed with all the Buddhadharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!
These are called the bodhisattva's sixty-seven pure precepts for purifying the precepts, which are inexhaustible.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!

Within the bodhisattvas' inexhaustible and pure precepts, there is no reliance on the self, person, sentient beings, life, nurturance, human being, form, feeling, perception, mental formations, consciousness, earth, water, fire, or wind.

these precepts are the characteristics of discrimination, because skillful means conditions all dharmas;

these precepts are the characteristics of emptiness, because attaining the limit of the signless is not mixed with the three realms; these precepts are non-action, because of the acceptance of non-arising.
Within these pure precepts, there is no past action, present action, or future action; these pure precepts do not cease in the past, do not come in the future, and do not abide in the present.
